node.title: Compiling from git source fails
node.bodyText:
even after pulling all the submodules I get:
make[1]: Entering directory '/work/00434/eijkhout/moose/moose-git/test'
/bin/sh: /work/00434/eijkhout/moose/moose-git/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
Did you run ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh? Are you using (and activating) our conda environment?

Was that script mentioned in the installation instructions? No, I didn't run it.
And I prefer to leave conda out of it because it messes with my environment.
Also: how do I specify an installation prefix location?

Which installation page are you following?
Conda is good at not messing with the existing environment. Unless nearly all the other tools (brew & pip are the worst offenders)

Cloning MOOSE

MOOSE is hosted on [GitHub](https://github.com/idaholab/moose) and should be cloned directly from there using [git](https://git-scm.com/). We recommend creating a directory ~/projects to contain all of your MOOSE related work.

To clone MOOSE, run the following commands in a terminal:

mkdir -p ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
Copy

commentnote

The master branch of MOOSE is the stable branch that will only be updated after all tests are passing. This protects you from the day-to-day changes in the MOOSE repository.
Build and Test MOOSE

To build MOOSE run the following commands:

cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 6

what s the link to this page? how did you reach it?
this is assuming the dependencies have already been installed

This information is on the Conda installation guide: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html, Under "Cloning MOOSE".
I think the issue involved, is due to a new terminal window being opened? And thus, we need to perform another conda activate moose, before proceeding with make

Well, that page is linked as
Installing MOOSE

To begin, click a link corresponding to your operating system or another installation method of choice:

    [Linux and MacOS](https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html)

so it's not specific to Conda, so I skipped the conda instructions, and when to the clone & build section.

@dschwen Ok, I'm calling install_and_rebuild which ends on
<<< Found PETSc 3.20.3 installation in /work/00434/eijkhout/moose/moose-git/scripts/../petsc ... >>>
checking whether we can compile a trivial PETSc program... no
checking for TAO support via PETSc... no
configure: error: *** PETSc was not found, but --enable-petsc-required was specified.

How do I debug that?
You run ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh first
Can you point me to full instructions for building from source?

Take a look at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
I think the root of the problem is that we don't explicitly cater to people who shun our Conda environment. The implicit assumption on our part is probably that those people don't require as much hand-holding. But they do deserve a clear pointer on our docs landing page.

Ok, I'll follow those instructions.
Eh, for installation on an HPC cluster I would expect a way to a set an installation prefix. That page assumes I'm installing in my home directory, which is not very HPC'ish, if you ask me. Which you didn't but I'm volunteering.

Part of the problem is that we run into so many folks that will literally cut&paste:
./update_and_rebuild_petsc --prefix=/path/to/desired/location
runs into an error, and then post it here about not having access to /path. 🤦
But, we can always assume ~/ is available. For the power-user such as yourself, I suppose I should create a specific help document. One that lists our working configure -- arguments, and that's about it. I myself would probably enjoy a page like this. Instead of having to cat moose/scripts/configure_petsc|libmesh|wasp.sh to see what I need.

node.title: 7 failed updated while reinstalling moose
node.bodyText:
I am reinstalling moose and the first time had no problems but this time I am having the same 7 errors show when i run the main test on moose.
utils/param_error.error ...................................................... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
parser/include.include ........................................................................ FAILED (CRASH)
parser/multiple_inputs.merging/three_inputs_error ............................ FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
parser/multiple_inputs.merging/three_inputs_override_message ................ FAILED (EXPECTED OUTPUT MISSING)
misc/hit_cli.merge ........................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/vanilla .................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/color ...................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4228 tests in 199.2 seconds. Average test time 0.3 seconds, maximum test time 12.2 seconds.
4221 passed, 96 skipped, 0 pending, 7 FAILED

Hello
We need the actual log, not just the summary at the end, to diagnose what is happening
If you run ./run_tests --failed-tests you ll see it
Guillaume
Its fixed but in the future I will try to give more information! thanks for the advice!

@Spudman105 -
Those specific tests failing probably indicate your WASP version is out of date with your MOOSE version.
If you are using conda packages for these components, you can update to the latest version by running:
conda update moose-dev

And if that does not work, then you can try to remove and reinstall a new moose conda environment with:
conda env remove -n moose -all
conda create -n moose moose-dev

If you are not using conda and are manually installing everything, you can run this from the MOOSE root:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh

I would suggest to then clean up your repo with git clean -xfd, rebuild MOOSE, and rerun those tests.
Note that git clean -xfd will delete any uncommitted work, so make sure you save your changes first.
I had updated everything earlier but the clean helped and I'm not getting any failed tests. Thank you!

node.title: Clone instructions do not mention submodule
node.bodyText: You're pulling in a lot of submodules, but the instructions under "Cloning MOOSE" do not mention that. As far as I can tell.

The reason we don't go to mention submodules during our "Getting Started" instructions, is that the user is either going to use Conda, which will include pre-built packages of all the submodules; thus not requiring any interaction with submodule what so ever.
Or they are going to build the dependencies themselves using the scripts found in moose/scripts. These scripts perform all the git submodule magic necessary.
I think the only interaction a user will require to understand the intricacies involved with submodules, is when they are actively committing to MOOSE; asking for a newer version of PETSc, for example.
I was going to convert this over to a discussion, but I am willing to leave it open as an issue, if we find that we should add submodule documentation that may be lacking elsewhere. But I truly believe it does not belong in the Getting Starting instructions...

Converting to discussions, this is not an issue.
We do not pull in any submodule by default. Only developers pull in libmesh & petsc, and some advanced users of the modules will use the saline, neml2, thermochimica etc submodules.
Ok, you can close this. Please address the other discussion that I'm failing to build from source.

Interesting... the update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh script should have pulled in all the necessary submodules. But it looks like it didn't for you, for some reason or another.
I've run into this error when building WASP as a Conda package. The solution is to recursively pull all of WASP's submodules:
cd moose/framework/contrib/wasp
git submodule update --init --recursive
... and then run the update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh script.
I am going to try to use conda to install moose. I want to use GPU but I don't know which step to make PETSc support cuda

@grmnptr I think there will be minimal changes required in order to use our Conda supplied packages along with Cuda support. I could be wrong. But I am actively creating Conda moose packages to support Cuda.

According to HPC download method, when I run update_and_rebuild_pets.sh script, I can modify configure_petsc.sh script to add with-cuda=1 to make PETSc support cuda but I don't know how to do other methods.

hmmm if that is all it takes to add Cuda support to PETSc, then yes sir! That should do the trick:
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --with-cuda=1
If you do this, and you are still wanting to use Conda packages, you should probably refrain from install the full gambit (don't install moose-dev). Instead, install what only is needed to build PETSc: conda create -n compilers_only moose-mpich.

I am going to try to use conda to install moose

But even this is not recommended if you are operating on an HPC cluster. Your cluster will most certainly already have a much-better MPI wrapper, than what we provide with moose-mpich.

I don't know if it's me or mpi.And I want to rebuild PETSc so that PETSc can support CUDA, I have changed configure_petsc.sh as shown in the figure.
#!/usr/bin/env bash
#* This file is part of the MOOSE framework
#* https://www.mooseframework.org
#*
#* All rights reserved, see COPYRIGHT for full restrictions
#* https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/master/COPYRIGHT
#*
#* Licensed under LGPL 2.1, please see LICENSE for details
#* https://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl-2.1.html

# Configure PETSc with the default MOOSE configuration options
#
# Separated so that it can be used across all PETSc build scripts:
# - scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
# - scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc_alt.sh
# - conda/petsc/build.sh
function configure_petsc()
{
  if [ -z "$PETSC_DIR" ]; then
    echo 'PETSC_DIR is not set for configure_petsc'
    exit 1
  fi
  if [ ! -d "$PETSC_DIR" ]; then
    echo "$PETSC_DIR=PETSC_DIR does not exist"
    exit 1
  fi

  # Use --with-make-np if MOOSE_JOBS is given
  MAKE_NP_STR=''
  if [ ! -z "$MOOSE_JOBS" ]; then
    MAKE_NP_STR="--with-make-np=$MOOSE_JOBS"
  fi

  # Check to see if HDF5 exists using environment variables and expected locations.
  # If it does, use it.
  echo 'INFO: Checking for HDF5...'

  # Prioritize user-set environment variables HDF5_DIR, HDF5DIR, and HDF5_ROOT,
  # with the first taking the greatest priority
  if [ -n "$HDF5_DIR" ]; then
    echo "INFO: HDF5 installation location was set using HDF5_DIR=$HDF5_DIR"
    HDF5_STR="--with-hdf5-dir=$HDF5_DIR"
  elif [ -n "$HDF5DIR" ]; then
    echo "INFO: HDF5 installation location was set using HDF5DIR=$HDF5DIR"
    HDF5_STR="--with-hdf5-dir=$HDF5DIR"
  elif [ -n "$HDF5_ROOT" ]; then
    echo "INFO: HDF5 installation location was set using HDF5_ROOT=$HDF5_ROOT"
    HDF5_STR="--with-hdf5-dir=$HDF5_ROOT"
  fi

  # If not found using a variable, look at a few common library locations
  HDF5_PATHS=/usr/lib/hdf5:/usr/local/hdf5:/usr/share/hdf5:/usr/local/hdf5/share:/opt/hdf5:$HOME/.local
  if [ -z "$HDF5_STR" ]; then
    # Set path delimiter
    IFS=:
    for p in $HDF5_PATHS; do
      # When first instance of hdf5 header is found, report finding, set HDF5_STR, and break
      loc=$(find "$p" -name 'hdf5.h' -print -quit 2>/dev/null)
      if [ ! -z "$loc" ]; then
        echo "INFO: HDF5 header location was found at: $loc"
        echo 'INFO: Using this HDF5 installation to configure and build PETSc.'
        echo 'INFO: If another HDF5 is desired, please set HDF5_DIR and re-run this script.'
        HDF5_STR="--with-hdf5-dir=$loc/../../"
        break
      fi
    done
    unset IFS
  fi

  # If HDF5 is not found locally, download it via PETSc and patch if on Apple Silicon
  if [ -z "$HDF5_STR" ]; then
    HDF5_STR='--download-hdf5=1 --with-hdf5-fortran-bindings=0 --download-hdf5-configure-arguments="--with-zlib"'
    echo 'INFO: HDF5 library not detected, opting to download via PETSc...'
    if [[ `uname -p` == 'arm' ]] && [[ $(uname) == 'Darwin' ]] && [[ $PETSC_ARCH == 'arch-moose' ]]; then
      echo 'INFO: Patching PETSc to support HDF5 download and installation on Apple Silicon...'
      PATCH_DIR=$PETSC_DIR/../scripts/apple-silicon-hdf5-autogen.patch
      git apply $PATCH_DIR 2>/dev/null || (git apply $PATCH_DIR -R --check && echo 'INFO: Apple Silicon HDF5 patch already applied.')
    fi
  fi

  # When manually building PETSc on Apple Silicon, set FFLAGS to the proper arch, otherwise MUMPS
  # will fail to find MPI libraries
  MUMPS_ARM_STR=''
  if [[ `uname -p` == 'arm' ]] && [[ $(uname) == 'Darwin' ]] && [[ $PETSC_ARCH == 'arch-moose' ]]; then
    MUMPS_ARM_STR='FFLAGS=-march=armv8.3-a'
  fi

  cd $PETSC_DIR
  python3 ./configure --with-64-bit-indices \
      --with-cxx-dialect=C++17 \
      --with-debugging=no \
      --with-fortran-bindings=0 \
      --with-mpi=1 \
      --with-openmp=1 \
      --with-shared-libraries=1 \
      --with-sowing=0 \
      --with-cuda=1 \
      --download-fblaslapack=1 \
      --download-hypre=1 \
      --download-metis=1 \
      --download-mumps=1 \
      --download-ptscotch=1 \
      --download-parmetis=1 \
      --download-scalapack=1 \
      --download-slepc=1 \
      --download-strumpack=1 \
      --download-superlu_dist=1 \
      $HDF5_STR \
      $MUMPS_ARM_STR \
      $MAKE_NP_STR \
      "$@"

  return $?
}

Using sudo while in a necessary environment (moose), will not work. Sudo will not pass/inherit your non-elevated permissions.
Is there a reason you need to use sudo at all here? It would seem you are operating within your home directory, negating the need all together.
Just FYI, to see what I mean about the environment differences:
conda activate moose
sudo env
and then
env

node.title: Accessing old documentation?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I was trying to refresh my memory on something and referred to your examples after a while. However, it looks like your block structure has changed a bit after the latest tagged release, lets take the most basic example found here. It looks like [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master] has changed to [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] . However, this produces the error for me since I am not on next but  2024-02-12 tagged release. If I change that directive back to the [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master] the example runs fine.
Am I missing something obvious about how to access old documentation online? I am currently building test_docs to create my local copy tied to the tagged release, so I think I should be fine, but it would still be good to know.

Hello
Old documentation is not accessible online.
You have to build it locally. Go in modules/combined and build the executable there
then do in modules/doc and run python moosebuild.py build --serve
after the website is generated locally, it will give you a URL to visit
Guillaume
Thanks! yes that makes sense, its useful to have moosedocs.py. I was curious if I was missing some ReadTheDocs style version tab in documentation.

node.title: several tests failed when installing on HPC cluster
node.bodyText:
I am installing moose on a hpc cluster. The compiling is ok but when I run tests, it reports the following error:

How can I detect what is wrong and fix it?

Hello
The skips are fine.
These diffs are due to a different version of exodus iirc and are not problematic.
To make sure, instead of pasting the summary, you can paste the log of the failed tests.
./run_tests --failed-tests will get you that
Guillaume
ok thanks!

node.title: How does MOOSE distinguish 2D plane problem?
node.bodyText:
Hi, everyone! I am a beginner for Moose. When I solve one element tension in 2D case, I find that the young's modules evaluated from the stress-strain curve calculated by Moose is different form that as the input material parameter. If the input young's modules is E0 and the Poisson's ratio is v0, the young's modulus calculated E seems to meet E=E0 /(1-v0^2).
For instance, I use the ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor material, e.g.
 [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 210e3
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  [../]


The input young's modulus is 210e3. But in the one 2D element tension experiment, the slope of stress-train curve is about  230e3. If I set the Poisson's ratio as 0, the slope of stress-train curve is about  210e3 correctly.

I wonder why the Poisson's ratio has an effect on the stress-strain curve of the one element tension in 2D case? The default 2D plane problem in Moose is plane stress or plane strain? And How could I set it?

Hi Yaode-Yin,
How did you apply the boundary conditions only at the corner points ?

Sorry to be late. Yes, the boundary conditions are only applied on the corner points (displacement-control loading on y direction). The numerical results should be in good argument with the exact solution of uniaxial tension.
Can you share your input file ?  I am also new to MOOSE. Was just curious
The default is plane strain.
If the default is plane strain, how can I solve a plane stress problem in MOOSE? How should I adjust the codes?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/WeakPlaneStress.html
Is it possible that one uses WeakPlaneStress and PhaseFieldFractureMechanicsOffDiag kernels together? I want to solve a phase field fracture problem in plane stress case.

Use mamba list moose-wasp and mamba search moose-wasp and make sure you have the latest version installed.

Thanks. If I understand the output, then my mamba install doesn't have the latest version. It's weird because I updated just 15 min ago and even cleared the cache from old packages. I guess I could try updating tomorrow to see if this really is just an unlucky moment.

hello
if mamba update moose-dev does not update this, delete the moose conda environment then re-install it
Guillaume

If you re-install the MOOSE conda environment, please don't follow the webpage.
The following command is outdated:
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.01.23
use instead
mamba create -n moose moose-dev

Indeed... there was an update recently where the file controlling what is labeled on the web site was not modified.
On it: #26957
Thanks All. I was copying the outdated command from the website. Works as soon as I switched to  mamba create -n moose moose-dev
